name: Magic: The Gathering - Duels of the Planeswalkers 2012

reviews.review_text: I bought this game when it first came out and it was fun whilst it lasted. Now there's never anyone online and the decks are broken. See*  It will never replace face to face MTG but for a few quick '5' minute sessions that can turn into hours it was, at the time money well spent.  *However since the last update all the decks I purchased (downloadable content) have now re-locked themselves and I refuse to spent anymore money paying for something I have already purchased.   It is a bug that has not been fixed and Steam are willing to sell you a faulty product and therefore i cannot recommend this game, I advise you to steer clear.

Offers plenty of content for newbies-to-intermediate MTG players.   If you're a long time MTG player who's looking for a similar experience online though - you won't find it here; the customization aspect of deck building in this game is quite limited.   Give it a shot if you're into card games or if you're a new MTG player who wants to learn/practice the basics.   Word of warning if you're gonna get this game: Almost all of the DLCs do NOT offer additional content (except for the expansion and Deck Packs #1,2 &3 ) as you are still able to get most of the unlockables by progressing in the campaign.
For old school fans who are looking to throwdown with some premade deck this this game is for you! So Good!
The 2012 update is more of the same as the original Duels of the Planeswalkers. An excellent conversion to PC of Magic: The Gathering. Highly recommended.

Great and addicting game. Thanks a ♥♥♥♥♥on to the guy who gifted it to me, everything with this game is great. It's not glitchy, it's SUPERB when it comes to noob-friendly (since I never played MTG at all in my life, although I have the basic idea about TCGs).  Really, I haven't had any problems or any illogical bugs and stuff like that, no game-breaking stuff which is usually the deal with these online TCG.  Most of the decks are balanced, and the mini-challenges which teach you about the game are a real treat and a fun thing for a non-experienced MTGer.  Very addicting, almost made me buy the DLC, and definitely will once and if it goes on sale. The multiplayer so far looks great, although I haven't tried it since I don't have many people who have this game, but if you ever get it, be sure to ring me up ASAP!  9/10  Very great game. Superbly executed.

This game does not allow you to build your own deck, but you can play with a dozen or so pre-designed decks with random limits on what cards of the same type can be in it. It also crashes, displays card graphics improperly, and cuts off the edges of the screen so you cant see or use cards on the side of the playing field. also it is very difficult to select or view enchantments on flying creatures.

This game had a big influence over me deciding to get into the actual trading card game. The game is easier to figure out than you would think, and Duels of the Planeswalkers 2012 makes learning the game mechanics and terminology even easier. All it took was the tutorial within the demo to make me go out and buy a pile of cards. This is considered the ultimate TCG, and I'd say that that is justified, having played various different TCGs in my time (Yu-gi-oh!, Duel Masters, Pokemon, Naruto, Digimon). Now that I think about it, this is the longest-running TCG on the market, and it didn't need a children's cartoon to be successful, and that should say something. It didn't take long for some of my friends to jump on the Magic train when I introduced them to it, and it's always good to have friends to play a TCG with.  So if you have any interest at all in trading card games, go download the demo.

I do not recommend this game for 1 reason. Buy the newest version. Wizards has improved the game every year and it is worth the price to upgrade. Unless you simply want to see the older decks, go for the most recent version.
HIGHLY addicting - especially the new ArchEnemy game modes.

Duels is an adaptation of the Magic card game, and I've enjoyed it. You select a pre-made deck to play with, beat AI opponents, and get more cards to add to the deck. The AI is mostly competent (unless, of course, they're your allies), and some of the matches can get pretty challenging.  In this version, they added the ability to swap out cards you don't like, and that's a huge upgrade from the previous version. Also new are Archenemy games, where one deck uses 'schemes' to take on multiple opponents, and these are mostly fun, though often frustrating and too luck-based.  The music and sound effects are bad. I turned them off.  I think it's worth it for $10. You can get a lot of playtime out of this, and the variety of decks keep the game interesting. If Magic sounds even slightly interesting, give it a try.  The bonuses in the Special Edition aren't worth it. The foil conversions are just cosmetic, the game's music isn't good, and you can find the comics online for free.
Interested in MTG? this is a great place to start !

2012 review: Outstanding casual game, provided you have some interest in a card game. It's pick up and play which is the best thing about it - no deck configuration required. If you grew up playing Magic like I did, I think you will enjoy this as I do.  2015 update: I am frustrated with all the different versions of Magic: the Gathering on PC and have a difficult time recommending any of them, let alone investing in them myself. At this point I think it makes a lot more sense to switch to Hearthstone since you know that Blizzard won't be abandoning it in a year with an entirely new Hearthstone 2016 product.
Classic gameplay and cool twist to an old school card game.
Quite a good strategy game, with pre-made decks adapted to different playstyles to which you can add through winning duels.

However, Magi: The Gathering - Duels of the Planeswalkers 2012 is a great game to start with if like me you are new into the geinre. Wait for the sales and get it.

New to the series, I didn't expect to be able to gather the mechanics of MTG so quickly. As a long-time Yu-Gi-Oh player, it took a while to train my brain out of some of their rules, but once I did I found myself equally addicted. I can't speak for all MTG players old and new, but my recommendation is so far based on pickupability, and the insane levels of detail the game goes into.  It's your classic card game you've come to love; we know that. The graphics for the cards are as always beautiful but what really sets it up for me is the amount of freedom I have in choosing what style and play type I want. From deck customization to multiplayer to co-op, there's no level of restrictions.   I need more time to play to be able to critique it fairly, but I know i'll be thoroughly impressed as I am now. I've become a MTG convert, which speaks for itself.   (Also, what an amazing opportunity Wizards of the Coast are giving to freelance concept artists.)

DOTP 2012 adds much needed interface improvements, more balanced decks (although I wish they hadn't gutted the U/B deck from 09.:() and a new co-op mode to the DoTP series. Pre-made decks are more customizable this time around, which is a huge plus.   This game is meant as an introduction to Magic and as such is casual friendly and easy to pick up, while still being pretty hard to master. If you're looking for a turn based strategy game, or want to get into Magic, you should definitely give this game a go.

If you play Magic then it is MTGO or MWS and this is all pretty irrelevant, but Duels is a good foot in the door for anyone interested in learning the game. You can't build or edit decks except to remove cards, so this is a very catered experience. I don't usually enjoy odd formats, but the Archenemy variant (1v3, in this case) is pretty fun. While limited in scope, Duels is significantly cheaper than going after physical or digital cards.
